topic.title: cf-mgmt Tool Example: Create a Micro-Cloud

body.p: In this example, all roles are installed on a single virtual machine. To avoid requiring a complete installation, this example runs in the Helion Public Cloud.

ol.li: Download and install the cf-mgmt configuration tool.
Register for a Helion Public Cloud account. Keep your username and password handy as you will be asked for them during installation.
Log into the Horizon console using the HP Helion Public Cloud username and password that you created during registration.
In the US West section, in the Compute row, click Activate to activate the Compute service. Activating the Compute service is required for creating VM instances.
Click the Project panel and then the Compute sub-panel.

Download the configuration file (RC file). RC files contain information about a hosted service, including region, tenant, and other information required to create a cluster. This RC file has been pre-configured for this sandbox project.
Click Access & Security and then click the API Access tab.
Click Download OpenStack RC file.

Create a key pair.
Click on the Compute sub-panel and then click Access & Security.
Click on the Key Pairs tab and then click + Create Key Pair.
Enter a name in the Key Pair Name field and then click Create Key Pair.

Save the keyPairName.pem file somewhere convenient. If you are not automatically prompted to save the file, click the link to download it. This file contains the RSA private key that you will need when you SSH into your VM instance.
Open a terminal window and change directory to the location where you installed the cf-mgmt tool.

Run the following set of commands to create the cluster.cf-mgmt.exe ^ --os-auth-url <OS_AUTH_URL from openstackrc> ^ --os-username <OS_USERNAME from openstackrc> ^ --os-password <OpenStack password> ^ --os-tenant-id <OS_TENANT_ID from openstackrc> ^ --os-tenant-name <OS_TENANT_NAME from openstackrc> ^ --os-region-name <OS_REGION_NAME from openstackrc> ^ create-cluster ^ --keypair-name <name of keypair created earlier> ^ --admin-email <email to use for admin login> ^ --admin-password <password to use for admin login> ^ --load http://clients.als.hpcloud.com/config/trial.yml
After the cf-mgmt tool creates the cluster, it displays the ALS Console URL. This URL will have the form http://api.<ipaddress>.xip.io For example: htttp://api.255.255.255.255.xip.io

Enter the Console URL in your web browser to navigate to the Management Console.You may be "warned" that the Console has a self-signed certificate or that the site is "not trusted". These "warnings" can be safely ignored.
You can now log in to the Console using the admin-email and admin-password values you specified when you created the cluster.
